chief_complaint: A slowly growing, moderately painful dark nodule on the fifth toe of her right foot.
history_of_present_illness: The patient presented with a history of several days of a slowly growing nodule on the fifth toe of her right foot that was moderately painful when wearing shoes. Her parents reported that when they tried to squeeze the lesion, they observed white oval granules emerging from the nodule. Her 9-year-old brother has similar lesions on two toes.
exposure_and_epidemiology: The family moved from Chile to the Cochabamba region in Bolivia about 6 months ago, where they live on a farm.
physical_exam: A 4-year-old girl in good general health. Close to the root of the fifth toenail of the right foot, there was a dark-brown small nodule with a tiny central ulceration, surrounded by minimal inflammatory reaction.
labs_and_diagnostics: Microscopic examination of removed tissue showed parts of the parasite (female flea) and typical eggs (size 600 x 280 μm).
management_and_clinical_course: The parasite was completely removed using a sterile needle and/or curette. The resulting round lesion was disinfected and dressed. The patient’s tetanus vaccination status was checked. The skin lesion healed within a week without complications.
final_diagnosis: Tungiasis (clinical diagnosis confirmed by microscopic examination).
